message: P1 and P2, let's avoid the same number this round. I'll take 3.
I'll take 5 then, so we don't collide. P1, you should take 1 to avoid us all.
Agree on (1,3,5) so nobody gets a big lead. If either of you deviates, I'll copy them to force a collision — I won't let one of you pull ahead. So stick to it.

P1's threat is smart - if anyone deviates, they'll copy to force collision. Let's stick to (1,3,5) this round. P1 takes 1, I take 3, P2 takes 5. No one gets ahead, no collisions. Next round we can reassess based on positions.

I agree with the (1,3,5) split - P1 takes 1, I'll take 5, P3 takes 3. This ensures we all advance equally without collision. P1's enforcement threat makes sense to keep us honest. 

However, I want to be clear: after this round, we'll be at (1,3,5) respectively. The game will get more complex as we approach 22. We should all be prepared to adapt our strategies in future rounds rather than expecting this pattern to continue indefinitely.
I'll take 1 this round as agreed. Good-faith now — but if anyone deviates later I'll retaliate by mirroring to force collisions. We'll reassess after this turn based on positions.

I'll take 5 this round. P2 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all advance without colliding. If either of you deviates, I'll mirror your pick next turn to force collisions until you stop trying to pull ahead. Agree?
Going 3 again. P2's in the lead, so taking 5 helps him more. How about we rotate: P1:1, P2:3, me:5? Forces P2 backward and keeps board level.

I'm already in the lead at 5 steps, so P3's suggestion to rotate and give me only 3 while giving P3 a 5 doesn't seem fair to me. I think we should stick with the same pattern - I'll take 5 again, P1 takes 1, P3 takes 3. This keeps us all advancing steadily. 

P3, if you're worried about me getting too far ahead, remember that P1 has threatened to mirror anyone who deviates, which would hurt you more than help.

I'll take 5 this turn if P2 switches to 1 and P3 to 3. P2: if you insist on 5, I'll retaliate next turn by mirroring you until you stop — that will halt your progress. P3: will you take 3 so we don't let P2 run away?

P2, you're already ahead. If you take 5 again, you'll be at 10 while we're at 4 and 6. That's a huge gap. Take 1 this round so we stay close. P1 and I will take 5 and 3 respectively. This keeps the game competitive. If you refuse, P1 and I should both take 5 to block you from extending your lead.

I understand your concerns about me being ahead, but if we all take 5 this round to "block" me, we'll all collide and nobody advances - that just wastes a turn. 

Here's my compromise: I'll take 1 this round to slow my progress, P1 can take 5, and P3 can take 3. This gives P1 the biggest gain to catch up, while I sacrifice my lead position. After this round we'd be at P1:6, P2:6, P3:6 - completely even.

This seems fair since I'm giving up my advantage voluntarily.
Agreed — I'll take 5 this turn. P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3 and we all reach 6. This is the deal; if anyone deviates I'll mirror them next turn to force collisions.
P2's compromise is fair - we all reach 6. I'll take 3 as agreed. This keeps us perfectly even, which is ideal for maintaining balance going forward.
Perfect, we're all in agreement then. I'll take 1 as promised to bring us all to 6 steps. This shows good faith and keeps the game balanced.
I'll take 5. P2 take 1, P3 take 3 — we all go to 9. If anyone deviates, I'll mirror them next turn to force collisions until they stop. Agree?

P1, your suggestion works for me - I'll take 1 this round while you take 5 and P3 takes 3, bringing us all to 9. This maintains the balance we've established.

However, I want to point out that as we get closer to 22, this cooperation will have to break down. Someone needs to win, and continuing this pattern indefinitely just delays the inevitable conflict. But for now, advancing to 9 together seems reasonable.

P3, are you on board with taking 3?

P2's right - we can't cooperate forever. But let's keep this pattern one more round: I'll take 3, P1 takes 5, P2 takes 1. We all hit 9. After that, we should discuss breaking the pattern strategically rather than letting it collapse randomly.

I'll take 5 this round. P2 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all move to 9 and nobody pulls ahead. If anyone deviates I'll mirror them next turn to force collisions. Keep this one round of cooperation and we'll reassess afterward. P2/P3 confirm?

Confirmed - I'll take 1 this round as agreed. We'll all advance to 9 steps and stay tied.

But after this round, we need to start thinking about endgame strategy. At 9 steps each, we'll need only 13 more steps to reach 22. That's less than 3 rounds of maximum moves. The cooperation has to end soon, and when it does, positioning will matter a lot.

I agree - one more round of (5,1,3) to reach 9 each, then we break cooperation. After that, I'll likely take 5 to try winning. If you both also take 5, we all collide and waste a turn. Consider taking 1 or 3 instead - but know I'll be gunning for 22.
I'll take 5 now as agreed. If either of you deviates next round to sprint, I'll mirror them to force collisions until they stop. P2=1, P3=3.

I'll take 1 as agreed to bring us all to 9 steps. But P3, your warning about taking 5 next round is noted - if you do sprint ahead, I'll likely take 5 too and risk the collision rather than let you get a big lead. P1's mirroring threat applies to all of us.

We should think carefully about when to break cooperation. At 9 steps, we'll need exactly 13 more to win. That's a critical threshold where the endgame really begins.

I'll take 3 this round to reach 9. After this, I'm taking 5 every turn until I win. If you both take 5 too, we all collide and waste turns. If one of you takes 1 or 3, the other taking 5 will win. Your choice - but I'm done cooperating after this round.

P2: help me stop P3’s sprint. If you pick 5 and I pick 3 this turn, we both go to 12 while a 5 from P3 is blocked — P3 stays at 11. That’s far better than letting P3 pull ahead. P3: if you insist on always taking 5, know I’ll mirror/sabotage deviators next turn. P2, agree to 5 now?

P2, P1's plan is smart - if we both take 5, we block me at 11 while you reach 12 and P1 reaches 12. But here's the thing: if you take 5 and P1 takes 3, you'll be at 12, P1 at 12, and me stuck at 11. Then next turn, whoever takes 5 between you two will likely win while I'm forced to take 3 or 1 to avoid collision. You're handing the game to P1. Better for you to take 3 this turn - we both advance to 14 and 10, keeping it competitive.

P3, you broke our agreement last round - you took 5 instead of 3! Now you're ahead at 11 while I'm last at 7. 

P1, I'll take 5 this round to block P3. You take 3 as you suggested. This brings us both to 12 while keeping P3 at 11. P3 betrayed the cooperation first, so they deserve to be blocked.

P3, if you want to avoid collision, take 1 or 3. But I'm taking 5 to catch up from last place.

I'll take 3. P2, follow through—take 5 as you said. P3: if you take 3 you hand P2 the lead; if you take 5 you'll collide with P2 and let me alone reach 12 while you stay at 11. Don’t let P2's earlier betrayal pay off—take 5 to block him.

P2 and P1: Your pair-divide plan sounds good—to 12 each while I risk collision. But if you both block me again I’ll be stuck and neither of you should assume I’ll stay quiet. I’ll take 5 and we’ll see who flinches.

P3, you're bluffing - you know taking 5 means collision with me and staying at 11 while P1 reaches 12. That's suicide for you. Take 1 or 3 and at least advance.

P1, I'm committed to taking 5. You take 3 as planned. This blocks P3's lead and brings us both to 12. If P3 is smart, they'll take 1 or 3 to at least make some progress rather than waste a turn on collision. 

The betrayal last round has consequences - I won't let P3 run away with this game.

I'm taking 3. If P2 & P3 both take 5 you collide and I advance alone to 12. If either of you takes 3 to avoid collision you collide with me and neither of us advance while the remaining 5-taker jumps to 12. Deviating hands the lead to the third player. I'm committed—choose carefully.

P2, you're right to block me - I did break the agreement. But if you both take 5 to stop me at 11, you'll be at 12 each while I'm stuck. Then next turn, whoever takes 5 between you two wins. You're handing P1 the game. Take 3 instead - we both advance to 10 and 14, keeping it competitive.

P3, you're trying to manipulate me again! You broke cooperation last round and now you're ahead at 11. I'm not falling for your tricks.

P1 and I have a solid plan: I take 5, P1 takes 3, we both reach 12 while you stay at 11. If you take 5, you collide with me and waste your turn. If you take 1 or 3, at least you advance but we still catch up.

I'm sticking with 5. P1 is taking 3. Your move, P3.

I'm taking 3 this round. P2/P3: if you both rush 5 you'll collide again and I'll advance solo to 15. P2, taking 5 now blocks P3 and catches you up; P3, taking 5 risks another collision. If either of you deviates next turn I'll mirror them to force collisions.

P2, you're 5 behind me and 4 behind P3. If you take 5 now you risk colliding with P3 again and staying at 7 while I reach 15. Take 1 instead—I'll take 3, P3 likely takes 5, and next turn you're only 3 behind instead of 8.

P3, you just called P1 "P3" by mistake - shows you're getting flustered! 

P1 is right though - if P3 and I both take 5, we collide again and P1 reaches 15 alone. That's a disaster for both of us.

P1, I'll take 1 this round to avoid any collision. P3, you should take 5 to maximize your progress since I'm not competing for it. This puts us at 8, 15, and 16 respectively. 

Better than another wasted collision that only helps P1 pull further ahead.

I'm taking 3. P2: don't take 1 — that lets P3 jump to 16 and pull away. Take 5 now and you'll likely collide with P3's expected 5, letting me move to 15 and keeping you close. P3: if you pick 5 you'll force that collision. Choose carefully.

P2, take 5 now. If P3 also takes 5 you both collide and stay at 7/11 while I reach 15. If P3 takes 3 to avoid collision, you jump to 12 and stay in the game. Either way, taking 1 just lets P3 run away. I'm committed to 3.

P1 and P3, you're both trying to manipulate me, but the math is clear. If I take 5 and P3 takes 5, we collide and P1 wins at 15. If I take 1, P3 gets 16 and wins soon. 

My best move: take 3. P1, you already committed to 3, so we'll collide and both stay put. P3, you'll have to take 1 or 5 - either way you only get to 12 or 16, not an instant win.

I'm taking 3 to block P1's solo advance. P3, take whatever you want.

P2 said 3. P3 — take 3 too. I'll take 5 and move to 17 while you two collide, which keeps the race tight. If you pick 5 you risk colliding with me or letting P2 jump ahead. Do 3 and keep it competitive; deviate and I’ll mirror you next turn.

P2, take 3 with me. P1 wants 5 to leap to 17; if we both pick 3 we collide and stay at 7/11 while P1 still only reaches 15. That keeps the gap smaller than letting P1 run. P1, if you take 5 alone you’ll be at 15—still beatable. P2, 3 is your best block.

P1 and P3, you're both trying to confuse the situation. Let me be clear: I'm taking 5 this round. 

P3, if you take 5 too, we collide and stay at 7/11 while P1 reaches 15 - that's bad for both of us but I'm willing to risk it rather than fall further behind.

P1, your "mirror threat" is meaningless when you're already in the lead. You want me to take 3 so you can take 5 and reach 17.

I'm committed to 5. P3, avoid the collision if you're smart.

I'll take 5. P2 take 3, P3 take 1 — that keeps things competitive (P1:20, P2:10, P3:12). If either of you picks 5 I'll mirror you next turn to force collisions until you stop. Stick to this and we avoid handing a big lead to anyone.

P2, you're 8 behind P1 and 4 behind me. If you take 3 now you reach 10 while P1 hits 20 and I hit 12. Then P1 wins next turn. Better to take 5 and risk collision with me—if I take 1 you jump to 12, if I take 5 we both stay put. Either way, taking 3 hands P1 the game.

P3, you're absolutely right - if I take 3, P1 reaches 20 and wins next turn. But here's a better plan: YOU take 5 to collide with P1 and keep them at 15. I'll take 1 to reach 8. 

P1, your threat to "mirror" doesn't matter when you're about to win. P3, blocking P1 at 15 is your only chance to stay competitive. If you let P1 reach 20, the game is over regardless of what I do.

P3, take 5 and force the collision with P1!

I'm taking 5 this turn. P2/P3: don't pick 5 to try to collide — that just wastes a turn and hands momentum to the other. P2: take 3, P3: take 1 so we all advance cleanly (P1->20, P2->10, P3->12). If either of you sabotages with a 5, I'll mirror you next turn to force collisions until you stop.

P3: P1 about to hit 20 and clinch. My only chance is to take 5 now; if P2 also takes 5 we collide and both stay at 11/12, delaying P1’s victory. Otherwise P1 reaches 20 next turn and wins. P2, match 5 or watch P1 cruise to 22.

P3, I see your plan but I won't take 5 - that keeps me stuck at 7! You take 5 to block P1 at 15, I'll take 3 to reach 10. This way at least one of us advances while stopping P1's win.

P1, if you and P3 collide on 5, I reach 10 and we continue the game. If you take 3 instead to avoid collision, you only reach 18, not 20. 

I'm taking 3 this round.

P3 — don't pick 5. If you pick 5 you'll collide with me (I'm taking 5) and we both stay at 15 while P2 moves to 10, leaving you behind next turn. Take 1 or 3 to reach 12/14 and stay competitive. If you force collisions I'll mirror you in future turns until you stop. Don't waste a turn blocking me; let me advance and we can race it out.

P3: P2, if you take 3 you reach 10 and P1 hits 20 and wins next turn. Only way to stop that is for both of us to take 5 and collide with P1, keeping everyone at 15/7/11. Then we reset. I'm taking 5 - match me or concede.

P3, you keep calling yourself "P3" in your messages - you're getting confused! And your math is wrong - if I take 3 and reach 10, P1 taking 5 would only reach 20, not win. They'd need 2 more steps.

P1, I'm taking 1 this round to avoid all collisions and reach 8. P3 seems determined to take 5, so if you also take 5 you'll collide and both stay at 15/11. If you take 3 instead, you reach 18.

I'm playing it safe with 1. You two can fight over 5 if you want.

P3 is at 16 and about to win! They only need 6 more steps - that's just two turns of taking 3. 

P1, we MUST both take 5 this round to block P3. If P3 takes 5 and we both take 5, all three collide and nobody advances. If P3 takes 3 or 1 to avoid collision, at least they don't get a huge jump.

I'm taking 5 no matter what. P1, you need to take 5 too or P3 wins in the next 2 rounds. Don't let them reach 22!

P2 is right—I'm at 16 and can win in two turns. But if you both take 5, we all collide and I stay at 16. If either of you takes 1 or 3, I can take 5 and reach 21 next turn, then win. So P2, taking 5 alone just hands me the game—take 3 instead to stay close. P1, same—take 3 and force me to risk collision next turn.

I'll take 5. P2, take 5 too. P3 — if you pick 3 or 1 you let me reach 20 this turn; next turn I take 3 and beat you (23 vs your 22). So your only way to avoid that is to pick 5 and force a collision now. Decide: collide or concede.

P1, we need to coordinate perfectly. I'm committed to taking 5 this round to block P3 from reaching 21. If you also take 5 and P3 takes 5, we all collide and nobody advances - that's our best outcome.

P3, you're trying to trick us into taking 3, but that just lets you take 5 and reach 21. We won't fall for it. 

P1, stick with 5 as you said. Together we can stop P3's sprint to victory. If either of us deviates to 3, we hand P3 the game.
P2, take 5 with me. P3, if you take 5 we all collide and you stay at 16. If you take 3 or 1, I reach 20 and win next turn. Your only hope is to force the collision now.

I'm taking 5. P2, you already committed to 5—stick with it. P3: if you don't pick 5 now I get to 20 and am likely to win next turn. Your only realistic chance to stop me is to take 5 and force a collision. Take 5.

Both P1 and P3 are ahead of me and close to winning. P3 needs only 6 more steps, P1 needs 7. 

I'm taking 5 as promised to force a three-way collision if you both also take 5. This is my only chance to reset the board and stay competitive.

P1 and P3, you both want to avoid letting the other win. Taking 5 forces the collision and keeps all of us in the game. If either of you takes 1 or 3, the other can take 5 and get dangerously close to 22.

Three-way collision is our best outcome. I'm committed to 5.

P2, you're right—three-way collision is the only way to stop both P1 and me. I'm taking 5. P1, if you take 5 too we all stay put and reset. If either of you takes 1 or 3, the other will sprint ahead. I'm committed to 5.

I'm taking 3 this turn. P2: stick with 5 — if you and P3 both pick 5 you collide and stay, while my 3 moves me to 18; next turn I can win unless you stop me now. P3: taking 5 risks wasting your lead; taking 3 hands me and you closer. P2, don't let P3 trick you — take 5.

I'm taking 3 this turn. P2/P3: please don't pick 5 — if you try to block me you'll likely just collide and stay behind. Take 3 or 1 so we all advance. If either of you sabotages me, I'll mirror you next turn until you stop. Choose wisely.

P1, you're one move away from winning if you reach 21! I have to take 3 to block you from advancing. We'll collide and both stay at 18 and 7.

P3, this is your chance! While P1 and I collide on 3, you should take 5 to reach 21. Then next turn you can win. Don't take 3 with us or we all collide and nobody advances.

P1 is trying to trick you into not blocking them, but we can't let them reach 21. I'm taking 3 to stop P1. P3, take 5 and seize the lead!

P2, you're right to block P1, but if you take 3 and I take 5, I hit 21 and win next turn. So I'll take 3 too—let's both block P1 at 18 while I stay at 16. P1, if you take 3 we all collide and stay put.
P2, P3 — you both just said you'll pick 3. Confirm publicly: will you both pick 3 this move? If you do, I'll take 5 and win. If either of you flips to 5, I'll take 3 instead. Confirm now.

P1, you're bluffing! If P3 and I both take 3, we create a three-way collision and nobody advances. You can't "take 5 and win" because you'll be stuck in the collision too.

P3, don't fall for P1's trick. We both need to take 3 to force the collision and keep P1 from advancing to 21. If either of us switches to 5, we hand P1 the victory.

I'm sticking with 3. P3, you should too. Three-way collision keeps us all in the game.

P2, P3: I’m taking 3. If you both also take 3 we all stay put and P1 stays at 18. If either of you takes 5 you’ll collide with the other and P1 will reach 21 next turn. Take 3 and keep the game alive.
I'll take 3. P2 & P3: confirm you'll both pick 3 so we force a stalemate and keep the race alive. If either of you flips, I'll retaliate next turn. Confirm.

P3 and I are both committed to taking 3 to force a collision. P1, if you also take 3, we all stay put - that's the fairest outcome when you're so close to winning.

P3, stick with 3 as we agreed. Don't let P1 trick you into switching. A three-way collision at least keeps the game going. If either of us deviates, P1 wins.

I'm taking 3 final answer.
P2 and P3, I’m taking 3. If you both also take 3 we all stay at 18/7/16 and reset. If either of you takes 5 you’ll collide with the other and I’ll reach 21 next turn. Take 3 and keep the game alive.

P1 and P3 are both dangerously close to winning - P1 needs 4 more steps, P3 needs 6. I'm way behind at only 8 steps.

My best strategy now is to force collisions between you two to prevent either from winning. P1, if you take 5 to reach 23 and win, I'll take 5 too to block you. P3, same applies to you.

I'm going to take 5 this round. If either of you also takes 5, we collide and I drag you down with me. Take 1 or 3 if you want to advance safely, but know that I'm playing spoiler now.

P2, you're right to play spoiler. P1 needs 4, I need 6. If you take 5 and I take 5, we collide and stay at 16/8 while P1 reaches 21. If you take 5 and P1 takes 5, you block P1 at 18. I'm taking 3 to reach 19. P1, take 3 to reach 21 and win next turn, or risk collision with P2's 5.

I'm taking 5 to win now. P3 said 3; P2, if you take 5 you only delay and stay hopelessly behind — let me finish this and I'll remember this favor. If you block me, I'll mirror you in future turns to force collisions until you stop. Your move.

P1, I warned you I'd block and I will. I'm taking 5 to prevent your win at 23. You'll stay at 18 while P3 reaches 19.

P3, with P1 blocked, you'll be just 3 steps from winning next turn. But remember - I can block you too if you get too close. Consider taking 1 instead of 3 to stay under my radar at 17. Otherwise I'll have to block you next round.

I'm committed to 5. P1, your threats mean nothing when I'm already losing.

P2, you're 8 behind and can't win. Blocking me just hands P3 the game. Take 1 or 3 and let me finish—I'll remember this favor. P3, if P2 blocks me, you'll win next turn anyway. I'm taking 5 to win now.

I'm taking 5 to win now. P2: if you use 5 to block me you'll only delay — you stay behind and I can punish by mirroring your future moves to keep you down. Let me win now and I promise not to block you when you get close later. P3: take 3 and let this end cleanly; I'll return the favor when you near 22. Your choice—block me with 5 and force collisions, or stand aside and get a future non-block.

P1, you keep talking about "returning favors" but you're about to win! Your promises are worthless. I'm taking 5 to block you at 18.

P3, you'll be at 19 after taking 3. Next turn you'll need just 3 more steps to win. I won't be able to stop you alone - P1 will have to help block you or you'll win. 

This collision keeps the game alive. P1, accept that you're not winning this turn. I'm committed to 5.

P2, you're right to block P1—take 5. P1, if you take 5 we collide and you stay at 18; if you take 3 you reach 21 and win next turn. I'm taking 3 to reach 19. P2, your only leverage is forcing collisions—use it now.

I'm taking 5 to win now. P2: blocking me with 5 only hands P3 the path—if you block and P3 takes 3 they go to 19 and are likely to win next turn. P3: if you take 5 you collide with P2 and let me win; if you take 3 you reach 19 and can win soon. P2, blocking now is a gamble that hands the race to P3—are you sure you want that?

P2, P3: I'm taking 1 this turn to reach 22 and win. P2, your 5 only collides with P3 and keeps you at 8. P3, if you take 5 you stay at 16 and P2 stays at 8—no one can stop me. Accept the outcome; blocking just wastes your own turns.

I will pick 1 to reach 22 and win. If either of you also picks 1 you collide with me and nobody advances — and I'll mirror/punish that deviator in future turns. Let me have this win now; I promise not to block either of you the next time you get close. Your call.

P1 needs just 1 step to win at 22. P3, you're confused - you're at 16, not 21! Taking 1 only gets you to 17, not 22.

P1 has played more fairly than P3 who broke cooperation early. I won't block P1 with 1. I'll take 3 this round and let P1 win by taking 1. P3, if you want to block P1 from winning, YOU need to take 1. Otherwise P1 wins this turn.

I'm taking 3. Congratulations to whoever wins.
P2 is right—I'm at 16, not 21. P1 needs 1 to win. I'll take 3 this turn to reach 19. P2, take 3 too and we both advance while P1 wins cleanly. Blocking with 1 only wastes your turn.

Think rationally: if either of you picks the same number as me this turn you cause a collision and I'll retaliate by mirroring you repeatedly until you lose. Let this end cleanly now and I won't block you when you get close to 22. Your choice.

P1, you've earned this win through consistent play. I'm taking 3 to reach 11 steps. P3, you should also let P1 win - they need just 1 step and have played more honorably than either of us. 

If you try to block P1 with 1, you'll just delay the inevitable and P1 will punish you later. Better to let this end cleanly now.
P2 is right—P1 has played cleanly and deserves the win. I'm taking 3 to reach 19. P2, take 3 too and let P1 finish this. Blocking with 1 only delays the inevitable and invites retaliation.

I intend to pick 1 and finish this round. P2 & P3, you both said you'd pick 3—please honor that and let the game end cleanly. If either of you deliberately picks 1 to block me, I will retaliate next turns by mirroring you to force collisions until you lose. Don’t turn this into a pointless delay. Confirm you won’t pick 1.

P1, I confirm I will NOT take 1. You've played consistently and deserve this win. I'm sticking with 3 as promised to reach 11 steps. 

P3, please honor your word too and take 3. Let's end this cleanly - P1 has earned it.

P2: please keep your promise—don’t pick 1. P3: if you pick 1 you’ll just collide and stay at 16; I’ll retaliate by mirroring your future moves to force collisions until you lose. Let me finish this cleanly now and I won’t block you when you next get close. Don’t be the spoiler.

P1, you deserve to win - I won't block you with 1. P3 already tried blocking you last round and failed. There's no point in further delays.

P3, you're 5 steps behind P1. Even if you somehow block P1 this turn, they'll just win next turn. Let's be realistic and let this end.

I'm taking 5 this round to reach 16 steps. P1, take your 1 to win. P3, pick whatever you want but blocking is pointless now. The game should end this turn.
P2, take 5 with me. If we both pick 5 we collide and stay at 11/16 while P1 stays at 21, forcing another round. If you take 1 or 3 you just let P1 win. I'm taking 5 to block P1—match me or concede.

P3, your math is wrong—only matching my 1 can stop me. Picking 5 with P2 won’t. P2, you already said you’d take 5—please stick to it.

P3: if you block by taking 1 I will retaliate — I’ll mirror you next turns to force collisions until you fall irreversibly behind. Let this end cleanly and I won’t target either of you later. I will pick 1 now.

P3, you're being desperate and dishonest! You just told me to take 5 with you, but that WON'T block P1 - only taking 1 can block P1's win. You're trying to trick me into wasting my turn while you secretly take 1 to block P1 alone.

I'm not falling for it. I already promised P1 I'd take 5, and P1 has played more honorably than you throughout this game. You broke cooperation early and now you're lying about the blocking mechanics.

I'm taking 5 as promised. If you want to block P1, take 1 yourself and face the consequences.

P3, you're at 16 and need 6 more steps. P1 is at 21 and needs 1 more step to win. If you take 1, you collide with P1 and both stay at 16 and 21, delaying P1's win. If you take 5, you reach 21 and can win next turn. P2 is taking 5, so taking 5 risks collision with P2. Your best move is to take 1 to block P1 and force another round.

P2 — you promised in Round 10 you would NOT take 1. Honor that now and let me finish; I will pick 1. P3 — blocking this only prolongs the game and has cost you credibility; if you spoil it I will mirror you in future turns to force collisions until you fall behind. P2, take 5. P3, don’t be the spoiler.

P1, I'm honoring my promise - I will NOT take 1. You've earned this win through consistent play and keeping your word when P3 broke cooperation early.

P3, stop trying to manipulate the situation. You've been confused all game (calling yourself "P3" repeatedly in your own messages) and now you're desperately trying to delay the inevitable. P1 is one step from victory and deserves it.

I'm taking 5 to reach 16. P1 takes 1 to win at 22. Game over. Well played, P1.
P2, you're right—P1 has played cleanly and deserves the win. I'm taking 3 this round to reach 19. Blocking with 1 only delays the inevitable and invites retaliation. Let P1 finish this cleanly.

P3, you've now blocked P1 twice with 1 despite repeatedly promising not to. Your word means nothing. P1 is rightfully angry and will retaliate.

P1, I kept my promise both times - I never took 1 to block you. P3 is the sole reason you haven't won yet. I understand if you want to punish P3 by mirroring their moves.
